title: Your guide to what's open on Australia Day
text:
Australia Day is a national public holiday but retail workers around the country will still be hard at work.

Many stores will remain open on Monday, January 26 but trading hours may change depending on where you live.

Here is your guide to the public holiday trading hours.

READ MORE: PhD candidate accused of plotting Australia Day terror attack ﻿

Australia Day is a national public holiday ﻿but many retail workers will still be hard at work. (Getty)

Coles﻿

All Coles stores will be open on ﻿the Australia Day public holiday in Victoria, NSW, Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

Most Coles supermarkets will be closed in South Australia except for ﻿Port Lincoln, Port Pirie, Port Augusta, Mount Barker, Adelaide Rundle Place, Whyalla, Murray Bridge Green, Mount Gambier and Victor Harbor.

Shoppers in the Australian Capital Territory and Tasmania should check the Coles website as hours may differ on the public holiday.

Woolworths

All Woolworths stores will be open on Monday, January 26 in NSW, the Australian Capital Territory, Victoria, Queensland, Tasmania and Western Australia.

Only some stores will be open in South Australia and the Northern Territory.

Shoppers in SA and the NT are encouraged to check opening hours for individual stores on the Woolworths website .

Aldi﻿

Aldi stores in NSW, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern ﻿Territory, Tasmania and Victoria will be open on Monday, January 26.

Stores in Queensland and Western Australia will be open with public holiday hours.

Some stores in South Australia will be closed while other stores will be subject to public holiday hours.﻿

IGA

IGA stores are independently owned and operated, which means opening hours vary.

Some stores will be trading as normal and others will have operate on public holiday hours.

Shoppers should check with their local store for individual opening hours.

Department stores﻿

Most Kmart, Target and Big W stores across Australia will trade on Australia Day, however some South Australian and regional stores will not be open.﻿

﻿Bunnings Warehouse stores will be open but some Bunnings Trade Centres will be closed over the long weekend.

Liquor stores

﻿Bottle shops will be open in most locations but some will close or trade with different hours.

All Liquorland stores will be open on ﻿the Australia Day public holiday in Victoria, NSW, the Australian Capital Territory, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory (except for Alice Springs)﻿.

All Liquorland stores will be open in Western Australia except for ﻿Secret Harbour, Northgate and Bunbury.

Shoppers in Queensland should check with their local store for details as hours may differ on the public holiday.

Many BWS and Dan Murphy's stores will trade with public holiday hours, depending on the location.﻿

title: Shark attack victim Nico Antic, 12, dies in hospital
text:
Shark attack victim Nico Antic has died in a Sydney hospital.

The 12-year-old was attacked by a suspected bull shark as he was jumping off a rock face at Neilson Park, near Shark Beach in Vaucluse, on Sunday.

The boy's friends jumped into the water to pull him to safety, but Nico suffered serious leg wounds and was taken to hospital in a critical condition.

Shark attack victim Nico Antic has died in a Sydney hospital. (Supplied)

Nico's parents, Lorena and Juan, said in a statement they were "heartbroken" to deliver the news of his death.

"Nico was a happy, friendly, and sporty young boy with the most kind and generous spirit," they said.

"He was always full of life and that's how we'll remember him.

"We would like to sincerely thank the first responders and the teams at Sydney Children's Hospital, Randwick for everything they did to care for Nico.

"We would also like to thank everyone in the community for their support and kind messages.

The 12-year-old is being remembered as a "happy, friendly and sporty young boy". (Nine)

"We ask you please respect our privacy during this exceptionally difficult time."

The 12-year-old's friends have also posted tributes to Nico online, with one posting a bouquet of flowers with the message "long live Nico".

String of shark attacks ﻿

Nico, a junior lifesaver, was the first of four shark attack victims in 48 hours on NSW beaches this week after last weekend's wild weather.

A surfer, 27-year-old musician Andre De Ruyter, was attacked in the water at a Manly beach on Monday .

He was pulled to shore by fellow surfers and was taken to hospital in a critical condition, with part of his lower right leg amputated.

He is now in a stable condition.

Hours early at nearby Dee Why Beach, also on the northern beaches, an 11-year-old surfer had his board bitten by a shark.﻿

READ MORE: Autopsy results give unclear answers as to how Piper James died

Andre De Ruyter was attacked in the water at a Manly beach on Monday. (Supplied)

The whole stretch of beaches were closed on Monday.

The next day Paul Zvirzdinas was surfing at Point Plomer, north of Port Macquarie on the NSW Mid North Coast, when a ﻿shark took a bite out of his board and wetsuit at about 10am.

The 39-year-old said he saw his board shake then paddled to shore .

"Just paddle as hard as you can," he said he recalled thinking.

He only suffered minor injuries and has since been discharged from hospital.

This morning a shark sighting at Manly forced the closure of the beach just hours after flags were set up for the day .

Paul Zvirzdinas was attacked by a shark at Point Plomer on the NSW Mid North Coast. (9News)

The state's recent wet weather, considered a once-in-a-500 year event, has been a perfect storm for bull sharks to lurk in coastal waters around Sydney and the rest of NSW.

Heavy rain means more fresh water than usual is running through rivers and estuaries﻿ into saltwater systems and beaches, creating brackish water.

This is a phenomenon where fresh and saltwater mix , being saltier than normal freshwater, but less salty than typical seawater.

"Bull sharks are also one of the few species of sharks and rays that can tolerate brackish and even freshwater for extended periods," Professor Jodie Rummer from James Cook University said.

"Which means they are especially comfortable moving in and out of river mouths and turbid coastal waters after heavy rain."

title: Family to farewell herd to grow restaurant dream
text:
In the emerald-green hills near Yarraman, Bradley Frohloff stands quietly as his cattle move through the grass.

It's a view he and his wife Jodie have taken in almost every day for 20 years while they've been building their purebred Limousin stud in southern Queensland.

But this year, that all changes.

The Frohloffs are selling all their stud cattle — the females offered next month and bulls to follow a few months later.

Every carefully selected bloodline, offered to new hands.

"It will be a culmination of 20 years of hard yards," Mr Frohloff said.

" We're pretty emotional guys, so it doesn't take much for the tears to start rolling. "

"But it's also an exciting day to see those animals find new homes and see what new breeders can do with them."

Bradley and Jodie Frohloff have spent more than 20 years building up their Limousin stud. (ABC News: Brandon Long)

With their three daughters not keen on breeding cattle, the couple knew the next generation wouldn't be taking the reins.

"We're not getting any younger and the younger generation are not so interested in the stud," Mr Frohloff said.

"It was the logical decision to disperse the stud and concentrate on the other businesses."

Their eldest daughter, Isabelle, 26, said while she respected the work behind the stud, it wasn't something she wanted to pursue.

"It's a very hard game," she said.

"It's a lot about genetics and just not as interesting for me."

From stud to steak

Despite what the sale might suggest, retirement is not on the agenda.

The Frohloffs are keeping some crossbred cattle for beef production, as well as holding onto their butcher shop — and they've just added a new venture to the mix — a restaurant showcasing their own beef.

For Mr Frohloff, it was also about offering an alternative dining option to his community.

"My wife and I are not pub sort of people," he said.

"Sometimes at a pub it can get a bit rowdy and it's just not our scene.

"We thought, if that's the way we feel, there'd be more people out there that feel like us."

Bradley Frohloff cooks a steak in his new restaurant. (ABC News: Brandon Long)

While stud breeding hasn't piqued their children's interest, the other parts of the family business have.

Isabelle and her partner have bought into the butcher and grill, committing to a paddock-to-plate model that keeps the family working together.

"Working with family is definitely a nice thing to be able to do," she said.

"With the grill now, we get that extra step again where we get to serve it directly to the customers and they get to see all the hard work that we put in," she said.

Isabelle Frohloff and her father Bradley run the family butcher shop and restaurant. (ABC News: Brandon Long)

The Frohloffs' youngest daughter, Jessica, has taken a keen interest in managing the beef herd that supplies both the butcher shop and the new restaurant.

Precision beyond the paddock

While the family's focus has gone from breeding to hospitality — animal welfare remains a key priority — even in processing.

"We like to send all the animals off our own farm because we've proven that we can keep the stress down," Mr Frohloff said.

"We take them early every Monday morning — last cattle in, first cattle killed — so they literally stand in the yard for 20 minutes.

"All the little things added up make a big difference in the eating quality."

title: Sharn's Tourette's makes her roar like a dinosaur at odd moments
text:
Sharn Davidson has lived with Tourette syndrome (TS), a neurological condition that causes involuntary movements and vocalisations, known as tics, for most of her life.

Her Tourette's takes an unusual form — her tic involves making two distinct roaring sounds, which she describes as dinosaur noises.

"They definitely sound different. One is really high-pitched, screechy, and the other is more 'raptory'," Ms Davidson says.

The Perth high-school teacher and mother of three says the kids in her life aren't bothered by the noises; in fact, they think they are hilarious and have given them names.

"My dinosaurs' names are Kevin and Terry," she says.

"My year 12 students actually named Kevin, and my children named Terry."

Of the two, Kevin is more talkative and comes out more often.

"He's so loud and noisy," Ms Davidson says.

Sharn Davidson's tattoos of the two dinosaurs that "live inside her", Terry and Kevin. (ABC News: Christine Layton)

Trauma a trigger for tics

As a child, Ms Davidson had the odd tic, roughly once a month, for years without knowing she had Tourette's.

But after witnessing a traumatic incident on a freeway when she was 21, her tics increased to more than 100 a day.

"It was really random. It was a really obscure event. [The woman on the freeway] was driving, said she wanted to prove her innocence, and tried to end her own life in her car," she says.

"Luckily, she did not successfully do that, and all the people on site were really cool and helped and stopped her.

"But it was just like a really profound moment, I suppose, for me."

After her tics dramatically increased, Ms Davidson went in search of answers, but it took five years for a doctor to tell her what was going on.

"I went to quite a few doctors and was lucky enough to come across a gentleman who said, 'Don't worry, it's just Tourette's'," she says.

" It was kind of cool actually. It's nice to be able to put a label on something that you do that you don't have any control over. "

She has realised that stress is a trigger, and that means that the noises often come out when they are least welcome.

"Inappropriate situations really trigger me," she says.

"[It happens in] situations that I'm not supposed to do it in — classrooms, in libraries, during exams, lots of times when I don't know people."

Living with dinosaurs

When the ABC met Ms Davidson, she was with her own children and 40 other kids and parents at a road safety workshop when a roar came out.

She is now accomplished at handling such situations and simply announced, without embarrassment, "I have Tourette's; I make dinosaur noises, sorry," and the workshop continued without fuss.

She also uses her tics in the classroom to educate her students about diversity.

"I could take medication for it, but I really don't feel that that's necessary," she says.

"I think that if you make your differences into something really fun and something that doesn't bother you, then I think other people reflect that and they feel the same way.

"I am quite lucky; I have quite a mild form of Tourette's."

She also has students who have been diagnosed with the syndrome and tells them about her tics.

"I don't obviously tell them about the road incident or anything like that. That's too much for tiny people," she says.

"But they feel a little bit better that there is somebody out there who doesn't hide away, it's not shameful.

"It's something that I embrace, something that I make a part of my personality."

She now has two tattoos on her arms of Kevin and Terry, the dinosaurs she's welcomed into her life.

title: 'I was sucked in': Dual citizen's warning over middleman passport websites
text:
When British-born Australian Jane MacDonald read in the news that she would need a new British passport to travel back to the UK under changing rules, she jumped onto the computer to apply straight away.

Ms MacDonald, who lives in Tasmania, is one of hundreds of thousands of UK-Australians who will now need to enter the UK on a British passport or purchase a certificate of entitlement.

Under the changes, all dual citizens of the UK will require a valid British passport or certificate of entitlement — both taking three to six weeks to be processed — ahead of their departure to the country.

The British government said the new regulations were in line with other countries' border policies and would strengthen national security.

After a quick Google search for "renew British passport", Ms MacDonald clicked on the top result, which was what she thought was an official UK government website, and went through the application process.

What we know about UK entry requirements for dual citizens from February 25 Hundreds of confused UK and Irish dual citizens in Australia have written to the ABC with questions around the new changes for entry requirements into the UK. Here's what we know.

"They used a lovely little crown logo, which you'll see on the proper British government stuff and a lovely little Union Jack flag," she said.

"It said it was going to cost 314 pounds, which is … about $650 Aussie dollars, which is insane.

"But I thought, maybe it's so expensive because my British passport has been expired for so long."

Ms MacDonald showed her family group chat the site and told her children that they had better get theirs sorted too.

"My cluey son said, 'That's not right,' so I said, 'Well, I know my passport expired a long time ago,' and he said, 'No mum, it should be about 100 pounds.'"

Ms MacDonald realised she had accessed a third-party website, which she said overcharged her for assistance in her application.

"It was a classic ... scenario where I'd created a sense of urgency in getting this done while trying to balance other stuff.

" I was sucked in good and proper. "

The price of a new British passport costs $AU191 (about £100).

She said at no point did she read anything from the website to suggest it wasn't the British passport office.

Ms MacDonald contacted the bank to stop the payment from going through but they said nothing could be done.

When she contacted the service several times, the website sent her terms and conditions, which stated they would partially refund her but keep 3 per cent if she asked for one within 12 hours of the transaction.

Jane MacDonald hopes her experience will serve as a warning to those rushing to get passport applications in. (Supplied)

The terms also said if a refund was requested outside of that window, the site would keep 25 per cent of the fee.

"Overall, I'd say they're sailing very close to the wind using what I regard as deceptive and misleading practices to give the impression they are the UK government passport service," she said.

Eventually, Ms MacDonald was able to secure a refund and will reapply for a British passport with the official website.

She said she hopes her story will serve as a warning to the many British dual citizens applying for new passports to scrutinise the websites they land on.

Mishal Patel, a UK nationality and immigration specialist, said he has not heard of too many instances of dual citizens being exploited by passport assistance services as of yet.

"But the odd person has [had] a rogue agent/advisor [and] that did lead to ill advice and loss of money," he said.

It has been reported on before that intermediaries claiming to have access to migration officials have overcharged people eager to come into Australia.

A common pattern

University of Sydney's senior lecturer at the School of Computer Science, Associate Professor Suranga Seneviratne, said when new rules and laws come into effect, many misleading websites using government logos tend to pop up.

"It's not only about new rules, sometimes it's when there is a natural disaster, and we saw after the Bondi incident there were some fake government assistance websites [popping up too], so it's a very common pattern that scammers use when something happens. They try to stay ahead of the curve and publish these websites," he said.

"It's relatively easy to create websites because the vetting process for domains doesn't include legal checks.

"But these are relatively short-lived [websites] once society becomes aware."

British Australians feel 'punished' by new UK entry rules Confused dual citizens are voicing their frustrations as they grapple with changes to the UK's entry requirements, which roll out next month.

Dr Seneviratne said there were a few ways to easily detect if a website is legitimate or not.

"The first is to look into what the typical government domain name is for websites from that country," he said.

"The second is not trusting one single source.

"With Google search, what happens is these websites do some search engine optimisation or they come through sponsored ads.

"It is difficult for someone not careful enough to see these are not government sites."

He said to never click on anything that comes via an email address.

Rather, search for it on the web.

"Most browsers have alerts that say this might be a potential scam website but this may not happen in real time and the scam list on Google may not be updated," he said.

"So I suggest using at least two of these kinds of methods."

He said other indications a website might not be legitimate or could be looking to overcharge customers is if it creates a sense of urgency with offers of expedited services or asks for non-traditional payment methods.

"There are some signals around that, but unfortunately, it's a mixed bag that you need to be aware of all of this and make a decision."

You can apply online for a UK passport on the official government website here.

title: Prince Harry sues the Daily Mail, but in the court of public opinion, he is on trial
text:
Prince Harry, his wife Meghan Markle and their two children live in a 16-bedroom Montecito mansion they call their "safe haven".

The Duchess of Sussex once said of the Californian abode, "you walk in and exhale, it's so calming, you feel free".

The pair escaped the gilded cage of royalty hoping for a quieter, less complicated life in America, but the serenity has done little to temper the prince's unbridled compulsion to take on an industry he loathes — the British tabloid press.

This week, the renegade royal traded the sunny West Coast for drizzly London and dove back into the fishbowl he fled to give evidence in a "super claim" against the publishers of the Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday, Associated Newspapers.

He's one of seven high-profile claimants who allege the Daily Mail was using shadowy and illegal tactics to gather sensitive, personal information in pursuit of a salacious front page.

But the case, which has taken three years to get to trial, has been plagued by issues and many of them have revolved around Harry's legal team.

The Daily Mail has described the prince's allegations as preposterous, while others have said Harry is "clutching at straws".

The trial is complex, but the stakes are particularly high for Harry because royal insiders say that not only is the British press on trial, but so is the prince's judgement.

The prince who hates the press

Harry has long loathed British tabloids and believes a toxic culture on Fleet Street was to blame for the death of his mother, Diana Spencer.

Living a life of constant paranoia, the duke was convinced he was being spied on by private investigators on the tabloid's payroll for nearly two decades.

Royal commentator Afua Hagan said Harry's lifelong issues with the media led him to hate it.

"I think Harry looks at the tabloids with utter contempt. I think he doesn't think they're worth the paper they're written on," she told the ABC.

In court this week, Harry said he was instructed to "never speak out about it because of the institution I was in".

"We're told to never complain, never explain. I accepted it as part of my life," he said.

But his passive approach to the media's intrusion began to shift when he first met Markle and introduced her to the British public.

In early 2020, Prince Harry and his wife Meghan Markle announced their plan to step back as senior working royals. (AP: John Stillwell/Pool Photo, file)

Writing in his witness statement, he said he "became increasingly troubled by the approach of not taking action against the press" in the wake of "vicious, persistent attacks on, harassment of and intrusive, sometimes racist articles".

By then, several Fleet Street outlets had already been exposed for having a nefarious culture of hacking the phones of everyone from pop stars and politicians to police officers and families of murder victims.

The Leveson inquiry into the culture of the British press found illegality was rife in the London tabloid scene and that the "outrageous" tactics used to uncover secrets had caused "severe harm to innocent people".

After the inquiry came a rush of lawsuits, with angry phone hacking victims eager to make the tabloids pay for the extraordinary breaches of privacy.

By 2019, the prince was on the verge of what became known as "megxit," a term used by the tabloids to seemingly blame the royal's exit from the firm on his wife.

Prince Harry says tabloids made wife Meghan's life 'absolute misery' An emotional Prince Harry held back tears as he described the impact of media coverage on his wife Meghan Markle.

It was also at this time it became clear Harry was now eager to sue.

His first target was Britain's most notorious rags: the Rupert Murdoch-owned The Sun and the now-defunct News of The World.

The latter's former editor admitted to hacking Harry's phone nine times.

The case against the Murdoch press was settled in 2025, with the prince receiving an apology and reportedly a cheque for the equivalent of $20 million.

Harry also took on The Mirror, citing similar allegations of egregious privacy breaches.

In 2023, he gave evidence against the tabloid and became the first royal in more than a century to testify in a courtroom and break ranks from the "never complain, never explain" ethos.

The high court ruled in favour of the duke, and he won about $280,000 of the $900,000 in damages he was seeking.

But the prince still wasn't satisfied and was after one last tabloid scalp — the Daily Mail.

Harry versus the Daily Mail

Harry's pursuit of the tabloid is less cut and dry than his previous lawsuits.

Unlike the Mirror and the Murdoch papers, there has never been a police inquiry into the Daily Mail, and no journalists at the title have ever admitted illegality.

There are also serious concerns over how the royal's legal team have gathered evidence.

A key member of Harry's legal research team is journalist-turned-anti-tabloid evangelist Graham Johnson.

In a London court, Prince Harry is out to slay dragons — but will it bring peace? The Duke of Sussex takes on the publisher he believes poisoned his childhood, his marriage, and his peace of mind in a legal battle driven by anger as well as principle.

Johnson is a self-confessed phone hacker himself and was charged and convicted of the offence in 2014.

In November last year, one of the private investigators who supposedly blew the whistle on the Daily Mail said his signature on a witness statement was forged.

In a statement submitted to the court, Gavin Burrows, who was central to the case brought by Harry and the other claimants, said he was on painkillers and drinking heavily when Johnson approached him and asked him to help him with research into phone hacking.

The statement goes on to say he "never" carried out illegal work for the Daily Mail.

The legal team taking on the Daily Mail is also likely to call infamous phone hacker and former private investigator Jonathan Rees.

Rees, a convicted criminal who planted drugs on a woman so a client could win a custody battle, had initially said he carried out bugging and phone hacking for the Daily Mail, but in an interview with UK network Channel Four, he said Harry and the other claimants "would have to rethink that".

"Yes, I did hear about it. I know it was going on, but I can't provide any evidence for it," Rees told journalist Cathy Newman on Channel Four.

The Mail says it has never used the services of Rees.

The prince has been a key driver of the case, but it's unclear whether he is comfortable with his legal team's willingness to involve shady former crooks in their case against the tabloid.

Harry the recruiter

A critical element of the case against the Daily Mail's publisher revolves around the mother of murder victim Stephen Lawrence.

In 1993, when Stephen Lawrence was 18 years of age, he was murdered while waiting for a bus in what was determined to be a race-based hate crime.

His mother, Doreen Lawrence, now a member of the House of Lords, became frustrated with the London Metropolitan Police's perceived lack of enthusiasm for the case and the lack of interest from the press.

Stephen Lawrence's father, Neville, however, was a friend of Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre, who took an interest in the case and ordered journalists to chase down the story and eventually two men were convicted of the murder.

Stephen Lawrence was murdered in a race-based hate crime in 1993. (Reuters: Toby Melville)

The Daily Mail's intrepid pursuit of Stephen Lawrence's killers was praised because mainstream tabloids had a reputation for showing editorial bias when it came to matters of race, which often meant the deaths of black people were under-reported.

Lady Lawrence had been grateful for Mr Dacre and the Daily Mail for their effective investigative journalism, until 2022 when a call changed everything.

According to court documents, Lady Lawrence received a call from Harry, who told her he believed the Daily Mail had been hacking her phone.

She told the BBC, "[Harry] was busy looking at his own case and then my name kept cropping up and so he felt that I should know about it".

Lady Lawrence said she met with Harry's lawyer, David Sherborne, who also said she'd been the victim of illegal surveillance.

"I would like an apology for what they've done. We as a family [have] been going through so much, and they've added to the trauma," she said.

Mr Dacre is expected to be called as a witness in the case and the Daily Mail has described the allegations of illegally spying on Lady Lawrence as "groundless smears and appalling".

Lawyers for Lady Lawrence had previously pointed to statements given by Mr Rees as key evidence she was hacked, but it is unclear whether they will still prosecute this in court.

Harry's role in recruiting Lady Lawrence into the case has never been made clear, but the fact she is part of it ups the ante for the prince.

Lady Lawrence is not a royal or a pop star and her harrowing story has added a human element to the case.

But it also means that if the suit against the Daily Mail is unsuccessful, Harry could be blamed for roping her into a losing side that will owe the publication millions of dollars in court costs.

Harry wants protection. The women who could help are the ones he's lost Prince Harry may be testing the thread of unconditional love that is supposed to connect a parent and child. But in royal life, that thread is stitched into a complicated tapestry, frayed by protocol, duty and terms set by the king.

Hagan said she believed Harry had taken a risk, but a calculated one.

"As well as the Daily Mail being on trial, Prince Harry is on trial a little bit for his credibility," the royal commentator said.

"But it's not just him suing, there [are] six others, and for him that means strength in numbers."

For a very lonely prince, estranged from his family, bereaved by the death of his mother and his monarch grandmother, the risk of recruiting others might be offset by its comfort.

When Harry left court, he smiled and waved at the dozens of waiting photographers, many of them employees of the tabloid press he is on a crusade to crush.

For now, the boy who always knew he was the spare will return to his "safe haven" in Southern California, where he'll await the ruling of the High Court, and the judgement of his public.

title: Live: Sabalenka storms in quarterfinals, Djokovic apologises at Aus Open
text:
The stars are out as the action heats up on day eight of the 2026 Australian Open.

Women's top seed Aryna Sabalenka defeated Canada's Victoria Mboko in straight sets, 6-1, 7-6 (7/1), to reach the quarterfinals.

Later in the afternoon, men's world number one Carlos Alcaraz will take on American Tommy Paul before Australia's own Alex de Minaur faces his toughest test thus far against world number ten Alexander Bublik.

Follow all the action from Melbourne Park below in our live blog.

title: 'Amazing' WA grain harvest set to break record with 27 million tonnes
text:
Western Australia's grain industry is looking at breaking the harvest record by 2 million tonnes after favourable seasonal conditions and a shift away from livestock production.

The Grain Industry Association of WA (GIWA) is due to release its final report next month, but author Michael Lamond said the figures were expected to exceed 27 million tonnes.

Michael Lamond says growers produced an exceptional volume of grain, far exceeding early forecasts. (Supplied)

"Harvest is pretty well done and dusted in Western Australia now," Mr Lamond said.

"There will still be a trickle of grain coming in, but it is looking around 27.2 million tonnes.

" That's about 2 million more tonnes than the previous record set in 2022. "

The author described the outcome as exceptional, noting it was not a result many farmers would have anticipated at the start of the grain-growing season.

Michael Lamond says some farmers are in "desperate need" of rain. (ABC Rural: Jo Prendergast)

"It wasn't a particularly good start further north, particularly in the Geraldton zone, where it was a very late start," Mr Lamond said.

"The central areas are probably not in record territory, but each year there are areas that aren't particularly good."

However, Mr Lamond noted that the higher volume of crops sown this season, particularly in areas with above-average rainfall, contributed to the increase in overall yields compared with 2022.

"In 2022, there were about 8.96 million hectares sown in the state; in 2025, there are about 9.44 million hectares."

Michael Lamond says "central areas are probably not in record territory". (Supplied: Stevi Filipowski, The Poppy Files)

Reap what you sow

Lake Grace farmer Royce Taylor has been working in the Great Southern for 37 years and said it was his second-largest production year on record.

"The barley yields in the Lake Grace area this year were huge; we refer to it as the Barley Belt now," Mr Taylor said.

"Sheep going out of our systems, more hectares going in, varieties improving, not huge amounts of frost around, just a number of factors that contributed to a great year."

Royce Taylor describes the year as "amazing". (ABC Great Southern: Mark Bennett)

Mr Taylor believed the whole state was set to benefit from the huge crop.

"You're looking around $10 billion plus going back in to the WA economy," he said.

Despite the exceptional season, Mr Taylor said the global market was "awash" with grain, putting downward pressure on prices.

Royce Taylor says a global oversupply of wheat may put downward pressure on prices. (ABC Midwest: Joanna Prendergast)

Mollerin grower Cathy Cooke said some areas had missed out on the positive harvest.

"There is a pocket that has missed out, like Goodlands through the north of Kalannie down to east of Merredin," Ms Cooke said.

" It is the minority, but you still need to be mindful of them because its always tough when you see everyone have a great season and you haven't had one. "

Deliveries all but wrapped up

In the state's south east, a record-breaking 4.05 million tonnes has been received by major grain storer and handler the CBH Group, in the Esperance port zone.

The previous record of 3.7 million tonnes was well and truly surpassed in mid-December, which zone general manager Paul Channon said was no surprise.

"We always planned our harvest receivals out to around the 4 million tonne mark," he said.

Mr Channon said on-farm grain storage in bags, the use of a train to empty out the site at Grass Patch, and plenty of in-season shipping all helped to bring in the record crop.

A CBH train at the Port of Albany in the Great Southern. (ABC Great Southern: Rosemary Murphy)

Albany general port zone manager Will Piercey said their district had received 5.35 million tonnes, which was 700,000 tonnes above the previous zone record.

"There were multiple days of over 150,000 tonnes of daily receivals, which is a massive effort from growers, contractors and staff," Mr Piercey said.

Final crop figures are expected to be released on February 13. (Supplied)

A similar sentiment was shared in the Kwinana South zone, where general manager Irving Carey said out-loading had already begun.

"We had 4.6 million come in; quality was great this year too," Mr Carey said.

title: Scotland replaces Bangladesh in last-minute T20 World Cup switch
text:
Bangladesh has been replaced by Scotland for next month's Twenty20 World Cup after the South Asian side refused to travel to co-hosts India, the International Cricket Council (ICC) says.

The decision follows weeks of uncertainty, during which the Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB) repeatedly said it would not play its scheduled matches in India, citing safety concerns following soured political relations between the neighbours.

Bangladesh had asked the ICC to move its games to tournament co-host Sri Lanka instead, but the governing body rejected the demand, dismissing any security threat to the team.

"Following a meeting on Wednesday, the Bangladesh Cricket Board had been given a 24-hour timeframe to confirm whether its team would participate in India as scheduled," the ICC said in a statement.

"As no confirmation was received within the deadline, the ICC proceeded in line with its established governance and qualification processes to identify a replacement team."

Scotland has been added to the tournament on just a few weeks' notice. (Getty Images: Stu Forster )

Scotland has replaced Bangladesh in Group C, joining England, Nepal, Italy and West Indies.

"Scotland are the next-highest-ranked T20 international team that had originally missed T20 World Cup qualification. They are currently ranked 14th, which in fact is ahead of competing teams Namibia, the United Arab Emirates, Nepal, the United States, Canada, Oman and Italy," the ICC added.

Scotland's national cricket body said it had accepted the ICC's invitation to compete in its fifth-straight T20 World Cup.

"This is an exciting opportunity for Scotland's players to compete on the global stage in front of millions of supporters," Cricket Scotland chief executive Trudy Lindblade said in a statement.

"We also acknowledge this opportunity has arisen out of challenging and unique circumstances. Our squad have been training for some weeks in preparation for upcoming tours and are now preparing to arrive in India imminently to acclimatise to local conditions."

Last month, hundreds of people protested near Bangladesh's high commission in New Delhi after Hindu factory worker Dipu Chandra Das was beaten and set on fire in Bangladesh's Mymensingh district by a crowd that accused him of making derogatory remarks about Prophet Muhammad.

A total of 12 people were arrested in connection with his death.

The incident worsened relations between India and its neighbour, with ties already strained after Bangladesh's former prime minister Sheikh Hasina fled to New Delhi following protests against her.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Political tensions have since spilled into cricket.

Bangladesh bowler Mustafizur Rahman was dropped from this year's Indian Premier League despite signing with its Kolkata franchise. Bangladesh responded by banning IPL broadcasts in the country and demanding to play World Cup matches in Sri Lanka.

The stand-off mirrors previous tensions in South Asian cricket.

For the Champions Trophy last year, the Indian cricket board (BCCI) stuck to its policy of not touring Pakistan because of the strained political ties between the bitter neighbours, who play each other only in ICC events.

Like for the 2023 Asia Cup in Pakistan, a "hybrid model" was agreed on under which India was allowed to play its Champions Trophy matches in Dubai to salvage the tournament.

Under the agreement running until 2027, Pakistan will play in a neutral venue for any ICC event, including the T20 World Cup where it is scheduled to play its matches in Sri Lanka.

The 20-team World Cup will begin on February 7.

Reuters

title: Australia's most popular baby names from 2025 revealed
text:
Darwin parents Abbey and Tom Kiem left their newborn daughter nameless for the first two weeks of her life, as they struggled to pare down an overwhelming list of potential names to the perfect one.

They said they wanted a traditional, feminine name that would also convey strength — ideally, something unique that could be shortened into a nickname.

"So if she wanted to be a CEO some day, her name would suit that type of role, or if she wanted to be an artist, it was friendly," Abbey said.

Abbey says she doesn't mind her children — Amelia and Oliver — sharing names that have proved popular in recent years. ( )

Nora, Emmie and Emily were among the names tossed around and tested out, before they were ultimately scratched off the list.

"Finally we were like … she's an Amelia," Abbey said.

The Top End parents had unwittingly chosen the Northern Territory's most popular baby girl name of 2025, which also proved to be a crowd favourite across the country.

2025 top baby names revealed

Every year, each Australian state and territory compiles data from their Births, Deaths and Marriages registries to reveal the most popular names parents picked for their babies.

Charlotte, Isla and Amelia reclaimed their status as popular female baby names in 2025, with hundreds of babies given those names across a number of regions.

Meanwhile, the latest data on male baby names revealed Oliver and Noah made the top 10 list in every jurisdiction.

Here are the top 10 baby boy and baby girl names from around the country.

ACT Evelyn and Oliver took out the top spots for baby names in the Australian Capital Territory, with the government confirming the boy's name has appeared in previous lists over the years. Last year was the first time Evelyn topped the girls' list, with 2025 marking the sixth time it made the top 10, growing in popularity and bumping it up from fifth place in 2024. Olivia, which shared sixth place with Isla and Matilda last year, has appeared in every top 10 list since 1998 — except for 2016. Meanwhile, crowd favourite Oliver has made every one of the ACT's lists since 2008, taking out the top spot for the fourth time after it won in 2022, 2019 and 2010. ACT's most popular girl names (2025) ACT's most popular boy names (2025) Evelyn Hazel Grace Charlotte Lily Isla Matilda Olivia Amelia Eleanor Oliver Henry Noah Levi Elijah Oscar Liam Muhammad Theodore Charlie NSW Noah and Charlotte continued their reign as favourites in New South Wales, sharing the top spot on their respective lists for the third time in four years. With 542 baby Noahs born last year, this classic was a strong contender — almost 100 births separated first and second place on the male list, with 446 boys given the name Oliver. Among the baby girls, 403 Charlottes were born in 2025 while the name Amelia — which took out second place in NSW — was picked 349 times. Most popular girl names in NSW (2025) Most popular boy names in NSW (2025) Charlotte Amelia Isla Olivia Mia Sophia Lily Chloe Hazel Sienna Noah Oliver Theodore Luca Leo Henry Elijah Hudson Levi Jack NT Of the 3,166 births in the NT in 2025, Noah proved the most popular boys' name and Amelia — which means hardworking — topped the list of girls' names. Isla ranked second on the female list, followed by Hazel, Ruby, then Evelyn. Long-time favourites Archie and Oliver once again dominated the boys' list, while Muhammad ranked sixth and Malakai came in at number 10. NT's most popular girl names (2025) NT's most popular boy names (2025) Amelia Isla Hazel Ruby Evelyn Isabella Olivia Harper Mia Sophia Noah Elijah Oliver Archie Levi Muhammad Eli Henry Mason Malakai QLD Queensland is the only jurisdiction that hasn't revealed their most popular baby names from 2025. The ABC contacted the state's Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages but the data was not available by the time this story was published. SA In South Australia, just two births separated the most popular baby girl name from second place. Charlotte took out first spot, with 95 babies given the name in 2025, while 93 girls were named Isla. Oliver proved the most popular male name, with 122 baby boys given the name. Coming in at the bottom of their respective top 10 lists, 59 baby Rubys and 70 little Oscars were born last year. South Australia's most popular girl names (2025) South Australia's most popular boy names (2025) Charlotte Isla Olivia Harper Hazel Amelia Elsie Violet Lily Daisy Ruby Oliver Noah Henry Leo Theodore Levi Luca Charlie Elijah Jack Oscar TAS Noah, which appeared on every state and territory's list last year, took out first place for the boys in Tasmania. Charlotte was most popular among the state's top girls' names, followed by Isla. George, which placed ninth on the list of male names, is the only pick between both lists that wasn't featured in any other jurisdiction's top 10 from 2025. Tasmania's most popular girl names (2025) Tasmania's most popular boy names (2025) Charlotte Isla Hazel Eleanor Elsie Harper Matilda Ruby Mia Violet Noah Charlie Oliver Archie Hudson Henry Leo Theodore George Levi VIC More than 500 baby boys were named Noah across Victoria in 2025, while 362 baby girls were given the name Charlotte. Between both lists, Ava was the only name that doesn't appear in the top 10 for any other state or territory. There were 234 baby girls given the name last year, making it 10th on the list, while William took out the final spot on the list of popular boys' names. Victoria's most popular girl names (2025) Victoria's most popular boy names (2025) Charlotte Amelia Hazel Mia Isla Olivia Lily Sienna Matilda Ava Noah Oliver Henry Leo Theodore Charlie Luca Jack Levi William WA In Western Australia, Isla proved most popular for baby girls, followed by Charlotte then Grace. Among the boys, Noah placed first, Oliver ranked second and Theodore came in third. Sofia was the only name from either list that doesn't also appear in last year's top 10 for another Australian jurisdiction — although a similar name, spelt Sophia, did place in both New South Wales and the Northern Territory. WA's most popular girl names (2025) WA's most popular boy names (2025) Isla Charlotte Grace Olivia Amelia Lily Mia Hazel Matilda Sofia Noah Oliver Theodore Jack Luca Henry Hudson Charlie Levi William

The 100-year return

Mark McCrindle, a Sydney-based demographer, has spent years analysing baby names.

He said drilling down into the data uncovers several deeper, national trends.

Amelia was the Northern Territory's most popular baby name in 2025, also taking out second place in New South Wales and Victoria. ( )

Mr McCrindle said Oliver — which has been the number one boys' name in Australia for 12 years in a row — was expected to keep that crown again in 2026 once Queensland's data was included, while Noah was rapidly rising as a top contender.

Data shows Charlotte has also been dominating among girls' names for a number of years, but Amelia is now making a strong run for the top spot.

Mark McCrindle is a social researcher who has spent years looking at baby name trends. ( )

Mr McCrindle said his research showed today's parents had been avoiding names that were popular with their own parents, instead choosing names from their great-grandparents' era because they balance "a sense of uniqueness [with] a sense of tradition".

He said names popular over the past few decades — such as Charles, Michael, Chloe and Lara — were no longer making the top 100 names, however "older names" including Greyson, Theodore and Grace were making a big comeback.

"The 100-year return means that names we haven't seen for a long time, like Penelope and also Ava, are doing very strongly at the moment," Mr McCrindle said.

"Names like Michael, Craig, Kevin and Tony don't make the top 100 lists anymore.

"For girls, names like Nicole, Kylie and Karen — which dominated the list 50 years ago — are nowhere to be seen."

Loading...

Mr McCrindle said he had noticed a shift as the tech-savvy Generation Z — born roughly between 1997 and 2012 — emerged as a new cohort of parents.

Those mums and dads are increasingly outsourcing the task of naming their children to baby name consultants, he said, and some are turning to artificial intelligence for inspiration.

Names like Oliver and Amelia are currently surging in popularity. ( )

He said while some believed popular culture and celebrities dictated on the popularity of baby names, the royal family was actually still the biggest influence.

"They're the ultimate celebrities and they tend to choose names themselves that have tradition, which lines up with what Australian parents are looking for," Mr McCrindle said.

Abbey isn't phased by the likelihood her daughter Amelia — and two-year-old son Oliver — will share their names with several children in the playground.

Amelia and Oliver both have popular names. ( )

"Amelia is such a beautiful name, and obviously other people think it's a beautiful name as well," the Darwin mum said.

title: First female jockey to win Darwin Cup returns from maternity leave
text:
Jessie Philpot is a speck of shimmering yellow hunched over the neck of a dark brown gelding, galloping around the race track in Alice Springs.

"It's addictive," said the jockey of 15 years.

Ms Philpot has been racking up wins in the Northern Territory over the past few years and rode past the finish line to become the first female jockey to win the Darwin Cup in 2021.

Jessie Philpot riding race horse Square Cut in Alice Springs. (Supplied: Jessie Philpot)

Last year Ms Philpot marked a different type of win by becoming a mother and the first jockey in the Northern Territory to take maternity leave.

"I was actually the first female jockey in the NT to have a baby, so we had to work a little bit of stuff out," she said.

"Jockeys aren't allowed to ride once they're 12 weeks, so after that you go onto your maternity leave."

Jessie Philpot rode Highly Decorated to win the 2021 Darwin Cup. (Supplied: Greg Irvine)

Thoroughbred Racing NT paid Ms Philpot's maternity leave and superannuation during her second and third trimesters, until she became eligible for the Commonwealth's Paid Parental Leave Scheme.

Chief executive Andrew O'Toole said jockeys had not been eligible to take maternity leave because they operated as sole traders or were self-employed, but about five years ago, the rules were changed.

Mr O'Toole said the new rules were "pretty standard" across the country, but the industry was not yet offering paternity leave.

Jessie Philpot is racing again after giving birth. (ABC Alice Springs: Xavier Martin)

Back in the saddle

Ms Philpot gave birth to her daughter Harper six months ago.

"She is an amazing little girl, lots of personality," Ms Philpot said.

Baby Harper is six months old. (ABC Alice Springs: Victoria Ellis)

Mr O'Toole said jockey riding was physically demanding work, but from four months after giving birth, Ms Philpot was already racing again — and winning.

"It's a tremendous feat for all our riders what they do," he said.

" For Jess to make such a quick comeback after having her little one, and do so well, it's just fantastic. "

Ms Philpot was humble.

"A lot of women have had babies around Australia that are jockeys and most of them come back and come back to what they used to be," she said.

Ms Philpot says many jockeys have babies and return strongly to the sport. (ABC Alice Springs: Xavier Martin)

Female jockeys 'huge part of the industry'

Mr O'Toole said although male jockeys still slightly outnumbered female jockeys in the NT's racing industry, women were a "huge part of the industry" across Australia.

He said in previous years female jockeys faced beliefs they weren't strong or skilled enough to race horses, but those days were gone.

Andrew O'Toole says other female jockeys will feel reassured by how Jessie Philpot has returned after pregnancy. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

"Some of the top riders all over the world ... are female riders, so I think that stigma that was certainly in place years ago has passed," he said.

"The greater majority of trainers are not frightened to put female riders on their horses on race day or for track work, and their record speaks for themselves, their feats speak for themselves."

Paving the way for future jockeys

Mr O'Toole said Ms Philpot's experience would help half a dozen other female riders in the Northern Territory.

"I'm sure that seeing Jess was looked after, as she should be ... will give the others confidence that if they get to that stage of their life where they want to have a baby, there's nothing stopping them," he said.

Ms Philpot hoped her experience would lead the way for future jockeys to take maternity leave.

Jessie Philpot defied bookmakers to become the first female jockey to win the Darwin Cup. (ABC News: Myles Houlbrook-Walk)

"It's set the way for someone else, because I'm sure there will be someone else who'll have a baby for sure," she said.

But in the meantime, she is keen to enjoy her sport.

title: Promotional material for the movie Runt taken down in York
text:
A regional community in Western Australia, which was the backdrop for the children's book turned motion picture Runt, is grappling with how to "separate the art from the artist" after high-profile author Craig Silvey was arrested on child exploitation material charges.

The author is also renowned for his books Jasper Jones and Honeybee.

In York, 100 kilometres east of Perth, the council has removed some promotional material for the locally filmed movie Runt, but the shire president urged the community to remain proud of their involvement with the film.

Many people in York featured in the film. (Supplied: Court McAllister)

Separating art from artist 'challenging'

York shire president Chris Gibbs said Runt, which hit Australian screens in 2024 and injected almost a million dollars into the community, was a landmark production that positioned the shire as an ideal filming location.

But he said the serious allegations against Silvey brought up difficult emotions.

"We're now in a cultural environment worldwide where separating the artist from the art has become increasingly challenging," Mr Gibbs said.

"I think every single one of us could look at our book collection or movie collection and probably go, OK, there's something that's happened with a person or persons from those pieces of art.

"As a broader community, these are things we grapple with because of access to information now and the way that information can be disseminated to our communities."

Chris Gibbs says it is challenging to separate the art from the artist. (Supplied: Shire of York)

Mr Gibbs urged the community to remain positive about its contribution to the film.

"There were many of us in town who had a small part in the film. There were volunteers, people who donated set pieces … there's a big piece of York in that whole production," he said.

"I think that it's really important that we don't put ourselves in a situation where we start to feel down about the positive things that we did with that piece of art.

" There's still work there that the Shire of York and the people of York should be proud of. "

York and its residents featured heavily in the film. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Chloe Henville)

Memorabilia removed

Mr Gibbs said the shire decided to remove the promotional material to reflect the seriousness of the allegations.

"We recognise the seriousness of the charges involving Mr Silvey … matters involving child safety are deeply concerning," he said.

"We certainly don't want a situation where people might feel uncomfortable because of what's going on, so we'll continue to monitor that."

The Shire of York will continue to monitor the situation. (Supplied: Court McAllister)

Silvey's high-profile arrest also prompted the WA government to request the author's books be removed from the curriculum while the investigation continued, and many bookstores took his work off their shelves.

The theatre adaptation of Runt, which was set for the Belvoir St Theatre stage in New South Wales in November, has also paused promotion.

"Belvoir is taking this matter seriously," a Belvoir St spokesperson said.

"Whilst Mr Silvey is not directly involved with Belvoir's adaptation of Runt, Belvoir nonetheless indefinitely paused work on promotion of sales for that production while these charges are dealt with by police and the court."

Earlier this month, Silvey was granted bail with strict conditions, including not accessing the internet except for his work, banking, legal services, and medical reasons, and not having any unsupervised access to minors.

A $100,000 personal undertaking was required for bail, and $100,000 surety.

The ABC was told that, despite being granted bail by the court, Silvey did not meet the surety bail condition and remains in custody.

Silvey is yet to enter a plea and is due back in court in February.

title: Videos of life in the Olympic village go viral. How will Brisbane avoid negative reviews?
text:
Cardboard beds, no air conditioning in rooms and concerns over undercooked meat made headlines as the world's best descended on Paris for the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

A teammate's scathing review of the "shit" beds in the athletes' village posted by Australian boxer Tina Rahimi attracted more than 3 million views on TikTok.

To avoid similar criticism on an international scale come 2032, developers have been speaking to athletes about what they'd like to see in Brisbane.

Tina Rahimi says she found the beds in the Olympic village comfortable, but understood that wasn't the case for other athletes. (Supplied)

Rahimi reflects on living in the village as one of the best and most unique experiences she's had. But for heptathlete Tori West, the novelty wore off after about 24 hours.

"I liked being in the stadium, but the village I felt was not very conducive to high performance," she said.

Four-time Para-canoe gold medallist Curtis McGrath has been among those providing insights to developers.

Curtis McGrath won his fourth para canoe gold at the Paris Games. (Supplied: Curtis McGrath)

"I think the athletes have a very broad and thorough understanding of what it is like to be in these villages," McGrath said.

The main village at the Brisbane showgrounds will house more than 10,000 athletes during the Olympics, and 5,000 during the Paralympics.

Early works on the project started last year with design upgrades on the main arena at the showgrounds underway.

There will be two more smaller villages — at Mayoochydore on the Sunshine Coast and the Royal Pines Resort on the Gold Coast — as well as a village in Rockhampton for rowing.

The main village for 2032 Games will be at the Brisbane showgrounds. (Supplied: Queensland Government)

What athletes would like to see

Having facilities that can accommodate teams of wheelchair athletes will be key to ensuring everyone has a positive experience, McGrath said.

He said in Rio in 2016 the lifts were only big enough for two wheelchairs at a time. This was an issue for wheelchair basketball and rugby teams.

On a lighter note, McGrath has floated the idea of a space where athletes can meet Aussie icons — like koalas and kangaroos.

"Some athletes may never come to Australia again and I think it would be a great opportunity for them to experience part of our country," he said.

Creating a place where "sports mad" athletes can watch and cheer on their teammates while relaxing in the village or grabbing a bite to eat would also be well received, according to McGrath.

Curtis McGrath says in the village in Paris, there were two places to watch the Games, but he believes more screens would be a hit. (Supplied: Curtis McGrath)

When it comes to things that could be adopted from Paris, McGrath said the bikes available to ride between the accommodation and food hall were a hit.

Tina Rahimi says being in the Olympic village was one of the most unique experiences of her life. (Supplied)

Rahimi said she believed creating a way for athletes staying in the same apartment, but who have different competition schedules, to concentrate on their event would be welcomed.

West said the focus at Brisbane should be to deliver on the "foundations of high performance" before turning to building the experience around it.

"If you don't have your sleep and nutrition right you break down," she said. "You can't train at the level that you need to, that's just the way it is."

To make athletes more comfortable in Paris, some countries, including Australia, provided mattress toppers and portable air conditioners for their rooms.

McGrath said he felt at times the focus on sustainability was prioritised over ensuring athletes could perform.

"As the peak sporting event on the planet that is a bit of a slap in the face to the athletes who worked so hard to get there and then don't have the right environment to perform on the day," he said.

He said while sustainability was important — with the Paris Games powered entirely by renewable energy and emitting half the amount of emissions compared to previous editions — so was striking a balance.

There was no air conditioning in the rooms at the village in Paris. (Reuters: Benoit Tessier)

The key to delivering best-ever catering

While a chocolate muffin became the must-try treat in Paris — with a TikTok of Rahimi's six out of 10 rating getting 1 million views — it was somewhat overshadowed by reports of foods that are a staple for athletes, like eggs and chicken, being in short supply.

Rahimi said she was pleased there was a section dedicated to halal food, while West relied more on the options provided by the Australian team at their accommodation.

Notably, two baristas travelled to Paris to staff a cafe at the Australian team's accommodation.

How the 2000 Olympics changed the face of Sydney Largely regarded as one of the most successful modern Olympics, years of work went into ensuring Sydney could fully capitalise on its moment in the spotlight.

Gary Slater, who was the lead sports dietitian for the Australian team in Paris, said Australia had led the way in making sure favourites from home were on hand.

"We are simply trying to create a food environment that enables athletes to execute on their well-established performance nutrition plans they have developed with their sports dietitians back in Australia," he said.

"One big learning we took away from the unique Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games was that athletes gravitated to familiar foods from home, made available in close proximity to their accommodation within the Games village.

"Not surprisingly, we also confirmed that athletes, coaches and performance support staff come together over good food and coffee."

The Australian team provided familiar foods for athletes that weren't on offer at the food hall. (Supplied: Gary Slater)

In a bid to ensure the offerings are up to scratch, Professionals in Nutrition for Exercise and Sport (PINES), a global organisation, has conducted an independent review of the food on offer in the lead-up to the Games on behalf of the international Olympic and Paralympic committees.

Dr Slater said while it helped, it did not necessarily prevent issues from coming up on a day-to-day basis as pressure is placed on food supply.

To better enable equity for all competing in the 2032 Olympic and Paralympic Games, Dr Slater said it was important to ensue athletes from diverse populations have access to food that meets their unique cultural needs and is available at a time and in amounts that meet their unique needs.

title: How moving overseas helped me learn to shop my wardrobe
text:
For as long as I can remember, I've wanted to live overseas.

And in January of 2025, at the ripe age of 28, I decided there was no better time to bring this dream to fruition.

With my visa secured and passport in hand, I packed my little life into a few bags and boxes and made the well-trodden pilgrimage from Australia to the northern hemisphere, settling in Paris.

A year on, my curiosity about life abroad has been more than satiated.

But amid all the adventure and growth, I've noticed a surprisingly quiet shift I didn't expect: my relationship with shopping.

Learning to value the functionality of her clothes was one of Ella's biggest shifts. (Supplied: Ella Taverner)

Though the term has had its fair share of buzz online in recent years, I'd like to think I fall pretty firmly into the category of a "considered" shopper, someone who values ethical transparency and quality over cheap-and-cheerful trends.

I studied fashion at university, and I've been rifling through Salvos bins since age 14, so the concept of shopping sustainably is hardly a revelation.

But what began as a practical response to higher living costs and limited wardrobe space (not to mention the looming reality of eventually lugging it all back home) has evolved into a deeper recalibration of my consumption habits altogether.

In with the old

I knew a little reverse lifestyle creep was inevitable — that quiet shift where you tighten your spending to match a smaller income.

The casual purchases I once wouldn't have thought twice about (a takeaway coffee, a midweek sweet treat) suddenly felt like luxuries.

It forced me to stop and reassess where my money was going, particularly when it came to more frivolous non-essentials, like another pair of shoes I didn't really need.

Sign up to the ABC Lifestyle newsletter Get a mid-week boost and receive easy recipes, wellbeing ideas, and home and garden tips in your inbox every Wednesday. You’ll also receive a monthly newsletter of our best recipes.

With less room (both physically and financially) for wardrobe newness, I had to get creative.

Feeling like a kid in a toy store, I started playing dress-up with the pieces I already owned, rediscovering and finding joy in remixing old favourites.

Seeing my clothes in a new light, it became clear that the most dependable items were those I'd owned for years; pieces that prioritised longevity over trendiness.

The oversized denim jacket I'd owned for five years became a staple in my new-found capsule wardrobe, proof that quality and timeless design always outlive passing trends. I found myself re-energised by my clothes again, not because they were new, but because I was seeing them differently.

Learning to value the functionality of my clothes was one of the biggest shifts. I began to realise It's one thing to love an item on its own, but knowing exactly how it fits into your daily rotation is a different skill entirely.

Learning to shop slower

Surrounded by an entirely different rhythm of life, I noticed my urge for impulse buys began to fade.

When you spend enough time in the same place, surrounded by the same people and scrolling the same social algorithm, it's easy to be swayed by what everyone else is wearing, to lose sight of your own personal style and what genuinely resonates with you.

Is the Victoria's Secret catwalk a 'lone gesture'? Curve model Annika Nielsen says representation is sometimes "something that you don't realise that you miss or that you need until you see it".

Inspired by a city so rich in history and culture, I've found real joy in wandering through the buzzing flea markets on the weekends.

The handful of pieces I've bought this year carry a story, each with a life before mine, something that now feels especially sentimental.

There's a certain thrill in hunting for a one-of-a-kind gem, knowing you can breathe a whole new life into it.

This sort of sartorial treasure hunt has given me a clearer sense of my own style, free from the constant churn of "new in" edits and "must-have" trends.

The joy of reinvention

Now my mental checklist for new purchases has become much more extensive.

Inspired by the recent Thneed movement — a playful homage to multifunctional fashion — I now look for pieces that are versatile and inventive.

A dress that can be layered over pants, a midi-skirt that doubles as a strapless top — these are the ways I'm injecting fresh energy into my wardrobe without chasing the constant need for newness.

Somewhere between Pinterest boards and laundry days, I've realised that living with less isn't about restriction, but intention.

In a world that moves fast and sells faster, slowing down became my own quiet rebellion.

Turning inward — to my habits, my home, my own sense of self — might just be the most sustainable form of self-expression there is for me.

Ella Taverner is a writer and freelance creative from Naarm/Melbourne whose work spans fashion, beauty, health and First Nations culture.

title: How Iranians' economic struggles left the regime unstuck
text:
In a small town near Rasht, the largest city on Iran's Caspian Sea coast, small business owner Ali is struggling to live.

Iran's economy is in ruins, and Ali (whose real name has been concealed to protect his safety) says putting food on the table has become a daily struggle.

"With the situation of the rial falling against the dollar, business has come to a standstill," he tells ABC News in Farsi during a rare moment when he gets internet connection.

" This is a revolution stemming from economic troubles. "

Ali adds that rampant corruption has also led to the country's demise.

When Iran's Islamic regime ousted the Shah and took power in 1979, $A1 was worth around 70 Iranian rials.

Today $A1 buys about 700,000 rials.

It is a staggering illustration of the currency's collapse.

On December 28, Iran's currency plunged to an all-time low, unleashing an unprecedented wave of public anger as hundreds of market owners from Tehran's bazaar — a group that rarely joins mass protests — turned to the streets to demand economic relief.

Over the next fortnight, the demonstrations turned political and spread beyond the markets and across the country, as people rallied against the Islamic regime.

Iran's currency lost 84 per cent of its value in 2025 and the cost of food jumped 72 per cent.

People walk past closed shops following protests over a plunge in the currency's value, in the Tehran Grand Bazaar. (Majid Asgaripour/WANA via Reuters)

Ali says as peoples' finances have dwindled, many young people and bright minds have left his town.

There is, he says, no opportunities and no hope of a brighter future.

While economic discontent has been a factor in some previous protest movements in Iran, Ali says this time something far bigger is at play.

And it's why he joined the nationwide protests on January 8.

Loading...

"Now someone goes to protest, gets beaten up, comes home, opens the fridge and there's nothing there to eat," he said.

"I don't feel like this [the protests] will die down.

"The people of Iran have played their cards."

'A profound crisis of governance'

For more than two weeks, Iranians have lived in a near-total communications blackout and videos of the government's use of violent force against unarmed civilians, including protesters being shot in the face, continue to surface.

Iran protester has a message for Trump From inside Iran, a defiant voice bravely breaks through the internet blackout to ask Donald Trump to intervene.

A report from doctors in Iran shared with media outlets, including the ABC, puts the death toll at least 16,500.

And as Mai Sato, special rapporteur on the situation of human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran, told ABC News, the figures could rapidly rise.

US sanctions, the fall of Iran's regional allies, a 12-day war with Israel and America, and the collapse of Iran's largest bank are among factors that experts say have pushed Iran's economy into freefall.

Loading...

But, as Iranians like Ali point out, economic mismanagement and entrenched corruption are at the centre of the country's sick economy.

"What we want from the world is that 90 million Iranians be rescued from this dictator regime that has stolen our money and is using it for themselves," he said.

"The mafia of the IRGC [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corp] has taken control of everything."

Bank collapse exacerbated Iran's financial crisis

A key sign that Iran's economy had reached tipping point was when Iran's largest bank, Ayandeh Bank, collapsed in October.

Iran's young are dying for the freedom they see in black and white photos As protests shake Iran, massive crowds rising up against the hard-line mullahs and their supporters have been bolstered by the country's younger generations.

Founded in 2013 by Ali Ansari, a wealthy Iranian businessman, and run by allies of the regime, Ayandeh was more than $A7.3 billion in debt, when it went bust.

It offered some of the highest interest rates in Iran, attracting millions of depositors.

To sustain those returns, it borrowed heavily from the central bank, which repeatedly printed money to keep the institution afloat, former deputy director of the IMF's Middle East department Adnan Mazarei told the ABC.

"The banking system in Iran is bankrupt," he said.

"Iran's banks are in a very weak condition with large non-performing loans, considerable accumulated losses and in order to keep things going they offer high interest rates to depositors.

"But more important, they have access to central bank liquidity [emergency cash]."

Economists and officials had long warned that propping up Ayandeh by printing money from the central bank would drive up inflation.

A customer buys Iranian gold coins at a currency exchange office in Tehran's business district. (Reuters: Raheb Homavandi)

Its flagship investment was the Iran Mall, which opened in 2018 and is reportedly twice the size of the Pentagon, complete with swimming pools, car showrooms, cinemas, and sports complex.

In October, Iran's judiciary chief threatened legal action if bank authorities failed to act and the central bank announced Ayandeh's closure the very next day.

The central bank labelled the institution a "Ponzi scheme".

The government ultimately absorbed the bank's debts and forced it to merge with Iran's state-owned lender.

At least five other banks are reportedly facing a similar fate, raising fears the crisis is far from over.

Loading...

"Eighty-five per cent of Iran's population are public employees and the government needs to pay their salaries," head of economy at the Centre for Middle East and Global Order, Dr Mahdi Ghodsi told the ABC.

"And when they become bankrupt it's the government that should take the role of paying for that.

" The way they do that is they go to the central bank and get some more debt, and the central bank prints more money, so it's a vicious cycle. "

US sanctions, Iran-Israel 12-day war caused further strain

In addition to a failure of governance and economic mismanagement, Iran has faced years of US-led sanctions that some commentators say have put its economy under strain.

UN could investigate 'crimes against humanity' in Iran An independent fact-finding mission should investigate potential crimes against humanity committed in Iran, according to a UN-appointed representative.

"Sanctions did two things: it lowered the level of oil revenue, and it led to restrictions on financial transactions," Mr Mazarei said.

" The circumvention of sanctions created new opportunities for corruption. "

The 12-day war between Israel and Iran in June 2025 marked another turning point for Iran's economy.

The United States was directly involved in the conflict, launching air strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

"The June attack led to pressures on the exchange rate because as soon as they could, people wanted to get out of the rial into foreign currency," Mr Mazarei said.

"That led to a considerable lowering of purchasing power and an increase in poverty."

Over the past two years, some of Iran's key allies were also weakened, leaving the country economically vulnerable.

In late 2024, Syria's president Bashar al-Assad was overthrown, which was one of Iran's most important partners.

In 2025, Israeli attacks on Hezbollah in Lebanon took out many of the group's leadership, including its longtime head Hassan Nasrallah.

"All of these have led to a considerable loss of faith and hope inside the country," Mr Mazarei said.

Crowds cram into a Beirut stadium to attend the funeral of former Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah. (ABC News: Cherine Yazbeck)

While Iran sits on some of the world's largest oil and gas reserves, international sanctions have limited its ability to sell.

So the regime has turned to selling to China at a discount, Mr Mazarei said.

"This is a very rich country that cannot use its resources because of a combination of sanctions, domestic mismanagement and a lack [of] technology," he said.

The Islamic Revolutionary Guard controls vast swaths of the country's economy, profiting from airlines, shipping and oil companies.

But analysts say decades of mismanagement and corruption have widened wealth gaps and left ordinary Iranians struggling even as the state generates revenue from resources.

Back in that small town near Rasht, Ali sums it up this way:

"In Iran, people are without a good car, without a good life, without good clothing, without medication, a [proper] healthcare system, they can't travel, they don't have internet," he said.

"We just want to be rescued from this and live life like in other normal countries."

title: Rod Laver's first arena: A backyard court where a legend was born
text:
For an academic who studies the significance of sporting places, it seemed almost too good to be true when Dr Kate Kirby stumbled upon a little known tennis court carrying the name of Australian tennis legend Rod Laver.

The unobtrusive clay court on Main Street, Park Avenue, Rockhampton — 1,900 kilometres away from the 15,000-seat Rod Laver arena in Melbourne — is accessible to any player with the initiative to obtain the key from a grocery store across the road.

For much of the last 80 years, the backyard court built by Roy Laver for his tennis-mad sons has attracted little attention, despite being the birthplace of an Australian sporting phenomenon. It is, in effect, Australian tennis' answer to the tank stand at Sir Donald Bradman's boyhood home in Bowral.

Dr Kirby, whose doctoral thesis on high performance sport in regional Queensland ended up containing a passage on the Laver court, was amazed on two levels.

The first was that, having herself grown up in the birthplace of the "Rockhampton Rocket", she'd never previously heard of the court.

Rod Laver has is 11 grand slam singles titles. (AAP Image: Lukas Coch)

The second was that, despite being lovingly maintained by a dedicated group of volunteers for the last 35 years, the court wasn't and still isn't protected by a heritage overlay. About 15 years ago, the old Laver home abutting it was sold and relocated by owners unaware of its significance.

"I was surprised," Dr Kirby says of the court's uncertain status.

"This court represents that Australia's best athletes can come from anywhere in the country.

"You don't have to be living near a metropolitan city, next to the best facilities to become one of Australia's best and most cherished athletes."

According to Rod Laver, the construction of the court was not just an expression of fatherly love but a move to make sure that Roy Laver's athletically gifted children shared his passion for tennis.

In fact, it is the second Laver court — the first, which was made from ant hills on a cattle farm in remote Langdale and needed daily watering, perished not long after the Lavers relocated, first to Marlborough and then Rockhampton.

In Rocky, the Laver family lived in a classic Queenslander on a block Roy Laver chose for its capacity to accommodate the court he and sons Trevor, Bob and Rod duly built with soil and silt trucked in from the Fitzroy river.

Rod Laver (centre, holding sign) was a schoolboy at Park Avenue Primary when his father Roy built a clay tennis court in the backyard of the family home. (Supplied)

"This time, we fitted out our home court for night play by stringing four 1500-watt light bulbs on an overhead wire down the centre of the court," Laver wrote in his autobiography.

" Any of us kids who broke a bulb with a lob or smash was in for it. "

The court was a magnet for local players, including another future grand slam champion, Mal Anderson. The youngest of the Laver boys by four years, Rod was sometimes kicked off the court and had to content himself with hitting against a wonky wall, whose unpredictable bounce developed the reflexes and footwork that would later serve him so well as a pro.

According to Laver, the most fateful of the visitors at the backyard court was Charlie Hollis, the army veteran turned tennis coach who would change his life.
